fieldData.faq-1-answer: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune condition where your immune system attacks your thyroid gland. It's the most common cause of hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) in the US.
fieldData.faq-2-question: How do you test for Hashimoto's?
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Hashimoto's is diagnosed by testing for thyroid antibodies (TPO and thyroglobulin antibodies) along with TSH and thyroid hormones. Superpower's panel includes all of these.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Hashimoto's is an autoimmune condition influenced by genetics, environmental factors, and possibly gut health. Women are 7x more likely to develop it than men.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: While there's no cure, Hashimoto's can be managed effectively with medication and lifestyle changes. Early detection allows for better management and symptom control.
fieldData.featured-testimonial-quote: "For years I was told my thyroid was 'normal.' Superpower found my thyroid antibodies were sky-high—I finally had an answer."

fieldData.condition-overview: Hashimoto's disease is an autoimmune disorder where your immune system produces antibodies that attack your thyroid gland, gradually destroying its ability to produce hormones.
fieldData.why-test: Many people with Hashimoto's are told their thyroid is "normal" because standard tests only check TSH. Antibody testing can detect Hashimoto's years before TSH becomes abnormal.

fieldData.faq-1-answer: Triglycerides are fats in your blood used for energy. Excess calories, especially from sugar and carbs, are converted to triglycerides and stored in fat cells.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Diet high in sugar, refined carbs, and alcohol; obesity; diabetes; hypothyroidism; kidney disease; and certain medications can elevate triglycerides.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Normal is under 150 mg/dL. Borderline high is 150-199. High is 200-499. Very high is 500+, which increases pancreatitis risk.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Reduce sugar and refined carbs, limit alcohol, lose weight, exercise regularly, and eat omega-3 rich foods. Medications may be needed for very high levels.
fieldData.featured-testimonial-quote: "My triglycerides were 350. Cutting sugar and walking daily brought them under 150 in 4 months."

fieldData.condition-overview: Triglycerides are blood fats that, when elevated, contribute to artery hardening and heart disease. They often rise alongside cholesterol and blood sugar issues.
fieldData.why-test: High triglycerides rarely cause symptoms until complications occur. Testing reveals your risk and guides dietary and lifestyle interventions.
fieldData.what-is-included: Your lipid panel includes: Triglycerides, Total Cholesterol, LDL, HDL, VLDL, and cholesterol ratios.

fieldData.faq-1-answer: Hyperthyroidism occurs when your thyroid produces too much hormone, speeding up your metabolism. It can cause weight loss, rapid heartbeat, anxiety, and tremors.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: The most common cause is Graves' disease (autoimmune). Other causes include thyroid nodules, inflammation, or too much thyroid medication.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Blood tests showing low TSH with high Free T4 and/or Free T3 indicate hyperthyroidism. Antibody tests can determine if it's Graves' disease.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Untreated hyperthyroidism can lead to heart problems, bone loss, and thyroid storm (a medical emergency). Early detection and treatment are important.

fieldData.name: Ferritin Test
fieldData.hero-headline: Test Your Ferritin Levels at Home
fieldData.hero-subheadline: Ferritin shows your iron stores. Low ferritin causes fatigue even when iron appears normal. Results in 5 days.
fieldData.secondary-keywords: ferritin test
fieldData.stat-1-text: most common cause of hair loss in women
fieldData.faq-1-answer: Ferritin is a protein that stores iron in your cells. It's the best indicator of your body's iron stores—more useful than serum iron alone.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Heavy menstruation, poor diet, gut absorption issues, blood donation, and increased demand (pregnancy, exercise) can deplete ferritin.
fieldData.faq-3-question: What ferritin level is too low?
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Symptoms can occur below 30-50 ng/mL even though labs may call this 'normal.' Optimal is often considered 50-150 ng/mL.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Iron-rich foods, vitamin C (aids absorption), addressing absorption issues, and iron supplements can raise ferritin over time.

fieldData.name: A1C Test

fieldData.faq-1-answer: HbA1c (glycated hemoglobin) measures the percentage of red blood cells with sugar attached. It reflects average blood sugar over 2-3 months.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Under 5.7% is normal. 5.7-6.4% is prediabetes. 6.5% or higher indicates diabetes.
fieldData.faq-3-question: Do I need to fast for A1C?
fieldData.faq-3-answer: No. A1C is not affected by recent food intake because it measures average glucose over months, not your current level.
fieldData.faq-4-question: How often should I test A1C?
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Annually for healthy adults. Every 3-6 months for diabetics or those managing prediabetes.
fieldData.featured-testimonial-quote: "My A1C was 6.2%—prediabetes. Diet and exercise brought it to 5.4% in 6 months."

fieldData.why-test: A1C reveals your true metabolic status over months, catching prediabetes and diabetes that fasting glucose might miss.

fieldData.faq-1-question: What does a kidney function test measure?
fieldData.faq-1-answer: Kidney tests measure creatinine, BUN (blood urea nitrogen), and calculate GFR (glomerular filtration rate) to assess how well your kidneys filter waste.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: GFR (glomerular filtration rate) measures kidney filtration capacity. Normal is 90+. Below 60 indicates chronic kidney disease. Below 15 is kidney failure.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Diabetes and high blood pressure cause most kidney disease. Other causes include genetic conditions, infections, and certain medications.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Early kidney disease can often be slowed or stabilized with blood pressure control, blood sugar management, and lifestyle changes.

fieldData.faq-1-answer: ApoB (apolipoprotein B) is a protein found on all atherogenic (plaque-causing) particles. It directly measures the number of particles that cause heart disease.
fieldData.faq-2-question: Why is ApoB better than LDL?
fieldData.faq-2-answer: LDL measures cholesterol mass. ApoB counts actual particles. You can have normal LDL but high particle count—ApoB catches this discordance.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Optimal ApoB is under 90 mg/dL for most people. Under 80 mg/dL for higher risk individuals. Under 60 mg/dL for very high risk.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Same approaches that lower LDL: diet, exercise, weight loss, and when needed, medications like statins or PCSK9 inhibitors.

fieldData.stat-2-text: linked to heart attack and stroke
fieldData.faq-1-answer: Homocysteine is an amino acid. High levels damage blood vessel walls and are linked to increased risk of heart disease, stroke, and cognitive decline.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: B vitamin deficiencies (B12, B6, folate), genetic factors, kidney disease, hypothyroidism, and certain medications can elevate homocysteine.

fieldData.faq-4-answer: Under 10 μmol/L is optimal. 10-15 is elevated. Over 15 is high and associated with significantly increased cardiovascular risk.

fieldData.faq-2-question: What's the difference between Type 1 and Type 2?
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Type 1 is autoimmune—the body attacks insulin-producing cells. Type 2 is insulin resistance—cells don't respond well to insulin. Type 2 is more common.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Type 2 diabetes can often be prevented or delayed with diet, exercise, and weight management. This is why testing for prediabetes is important.
fieldData.faq-4-question: Should I get tested even without symptoms?
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Yes. Type 2 diabetes often has no symptoms for years. Testing is recommended for everyone over 45 or those with risk factors.

fieldData.name: Celiac Test

fieldData.faq-1-question: How accurate is celiac blood testing?
fieldData.faq-1-answer: tTG-IgA has 95%+ sensitivity and specificity when you're eating gluten. Positive results require biopsy confirmation; negative results generally rule it out.
fieldData.faq-2-question: Can I test if I'm already gluten-free?
fieldData.faq-2-answer: No. You must be eating gluten (equivalent to 1-2 slices of bread daily) for at least 2-4 weeks before testing for accurate results.
fieldData.faq-3-question: What if the test is negative but I react to gluten?
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Negative celiac testing with gluten symptoms may indicate non-celiac gluten sensitivity—a different condition that doesn't damage the gut.
fieldData.faq-4-question: Is celiac the same as gluten sensitivity?
fieldData.faq-4-answer: No. Celiac is an autoimmune disease with intestinal damage. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity causes symptoms without the autoimmune response or damage.
fieldData.featured-testimonial-quote: "Testing confirmed celiac disease that doctors missed for 15 years. Finally have an answer and a solution."

fieldData.name: LDL vs HDL

fieldData.hero-subheadline: Understand your good and bad cholesterol. The balance matters for heart health. Results in 5 days.
fieldData.secondary-keywords: hdl vs ldl cholesterol, ldl hdl triglycerides
fieldData.faq-1-answer: LDL (low-density lipoprotein) carries cholesterol to arteries where it can build up as plaque. It's called 'bad' cholesterol because high levels increase heart disease risk.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: HDL (high-density lipoprotein) carries cholesterol away from arteries to the liver for removal. It's called 'good' cholesterol because higher levels are protective.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Lower is better. A ratio under 2.0 is ideal. Over 5.0 indicates high cardiovascular risk.
fieldData.faq-4-question: How do I improve my ratio?
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Exercise raises HDL. Diet, weight loss, and sometimes medication lower LDL. Both improve the ratio.
fieldData.featured-testimonial-quote: "My LDL/HDL ratio was 4.5. Exercise and diet got it down to 2.0 in a year."

fieldData.meta-description: Test LDL and HDL cholesterol at home. Understand good vs bad cholesterol. Results in 5 days. Only $17/month.
fieldData.condition-overview: LDL and HDL cholesterol have opposite effects on heart health. The balance between them—not just total cholesterol—determines cardiovascular risk.
fieldData.why-test: Testing both LDL and HDL reveals your actual cardiovascular risk. High LDL with low HDL is particularly dangerous.
fieldData.what-is-included: Your panel includes: LDL, HDL, Total Cholesterol, Triglycerides, VLDL, and cholesterol ratios.
fieldData.next-steps: Our care team explains your LDL/HDL balance and provides targeted recommendations to optimize both numbers.

fieldData.faq-1-answer: PSA (prostate-specific antigen) is a protein made by the prostate. Elevated levels may indicate prostate cancer, but can also be elevated due to benign conditions.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Generally, PSA below 4 ng/mL is considered normal. 4-10 ng/mL warrants further evaluation. Over 10 ng/mL is more concerning. Trends matter too.
fieldData.faq-3-question: Can PSA be elevated without cancer?
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Yes. Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), prostatitis, recent ejaculation, and age can elevate PSA. An elevated PSA doesn't mean you have cancer.
fieldData.faq-4-question: How often should I test PSA?
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Discuss with your doctor based on risk factors. Many men start annual testing at 50 (or earlier with risk factors). Tracking trends is important.

fieldData.faq-3-answer: Fatty fish, fortified foods, and egg yolks have some vitamin D, but it's difficult to get optimal amounts from diet alone.
fieldData.faq-4-question: How much vitamin D do I need?
fieldData.faq-4-answer: It depends on your current level. Testing determines your needs—typically 1,000-5,000 IU daily for most adults.

fieldData.faq-1-answer: Hypothyroidism means your thyroid doesn't produce enough hormone, slowing your metabolism. It causes fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and brain fog.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: The most common cause is Hashimoto's disease (autoimmune). Other causes include thyroid surgery, radiation, certain medications, or iodine deficiency.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Blood tests showing elevated TSH and low Free T4 indicate hypothyroidism. Antibody tests determine if Hashimoto's is the cause.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Yes, very effectively. Thyroid hormone replacement medication restores normal levels. Most people feel significantly better within weeks of starting treatment.

fieldData.condition-overview: Hypothyroidism occurs when your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough hormone. This slows your metabolism and affects energy, weight, mood, and virtually every body system.
fieldData.why-test: Hypothyroidism is often missed or undertreated. Comprehensive testing including antibodies helps identify the cause and ensures appropriate treatment.

fieldData.name: GFR Test
fieldData.hero-subheadline: GFR measures kidney filtration rate—the best indicator of kidney health. Simple blood test, results in 5 days.
fieldData.faq-1-answer: GFR (glomerular filtration rate) measures how much blood your kidneys filter per minute. It's the best overall indicator of kidney function.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: 90+ is normal. 60-89 may indicate mild decrease. 30-59 is moderate kidney disease. 15-29 is severe. Below 15 is kidney failure.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: GFR is estimated from blood creatinine level, age, sex, and race using a formula. Superpower reports eGFR (estimated GFR).
fieldData.faq-4-answer: GFR can sometimes improve with treatment of underlying causes. More often, the goal is preventing further decline.
fieldData.featured-testimonial-quote: "As a diabetic, I monitor my GFR annually. It's the best way to catch kidney problems early."
fieldData.meta-title: GFR Test at Home | Kidney Filtration Rate | Superpower
fieldData.meta-description: Check your GFR (glomerular filtration rate) at home. Best indicator of kidney health. Results in 5 days. Only $17/month.
fieldData.condition-overview: GFR tells you how well your kidneys are filtering. It's the gold standard for assessing kidney function and staging kidney disease.
fieldData.why-test: GFR catches kidney decline before symptoms appear. Essential monitoring for anyone with diabetes, hypertension, or kidney disease risk factors.
fieldData.what-is-included: Your panel calculates eGFR from creatinine and includes BUN and electrolytes for complete kidney assessment.
fieldData.next-steps: Our care team explains your GFR in context and recommends monitoring frequency based on your results and risk factors.

fieldData.faq-1-question: Can I get vitamin D from sun?
fieldData.faq-1-answer: Yes, but only under specific conditions: midday sun, exposed skin, without sunscreen, during summer months at sufficient latitude.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Yes, SPF 15+ blocks 99% of vitamin D production. This creates a tradeoff between skin cancer prevention and vitamin D.
fieldData.faq-3-question: Why can't I get enough from sun?
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Many factors limit sun-derived vitamin D: indoor lifestyle, northern latitude, dark skin, sunscreen use, and winter months.
fieldData.faq-4-question: Should I supplement or get more sun?
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Most people need supplementation. Testing shows whether your current sun exposure is sufficient or if you need supplements.

fieldData.name: B12 Test
fieldData.hero-subheadline: B12 deficiency causes fatigue, brain fog, and nerve problems. Check your levels. Results in 5 days.
fieldData.faq-1-answer: Vitamin B12 is essential for nerve function, DNA synthesis, and red blood cell formation. Your body doesn't make it—you must get it from food or supplements.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Vegetarian/vegan diet, malabsorption (Crohn's, celiac, gastric surgery), older age, and certain medications (metformin, PPIs) can cause deficiency.
fieldData.faq-3-question: What level of B12 is too low?
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Below 200 pg/mL is deficient. 200-400 pg/mL may still cause symptoms in some people. Optimal is often considered 500+ pg/mL.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: B12 is found in animal products. Vegetarians need supplements. Absorption issues may require high-dose oral or injectable B12.

fieldData.faq-1-question: What does an iron test include?
fieldData.faq-1-answer: Complete iron studies include serum iron, ferritin (stores), TIBC, and transferrin saturation. All are needed for accurate assessment.
fieldData.faq-2-question: Can iron be normal but ferritin low?
fieldData.faq-2-answer: Yes. Ferritin drops first when stores are depleted. You can have symptoms with low ferritin even if serum iron appears normal.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: Heavy menstruation, poor diet, blood loss, gut absorption issues, and increased needs (pregnancy, athletes) can cause deficiency.
fieldData.faq-4-answer: Only if testing shows deficiency. Unnecessary iron supplementation can be harmful. Test first, then supplement appropriately.

fieldData.name: BUN Test
fieldData.hero-subheadline: Check blood urea nitrogen levels to assess kidney function and hydration. Simple test, results in 5 days.
fieldData.primary-keyword: what causes low blood urea nitrogen
fieldData.faq-1-answer: BUN (blood urea nitrogen) measures nitrogen in blood from protein breakdown. High BUN can indicate kidney problems, dehydration, or high protein intake.
fieldData.faq-2-answer: High BUN can result from kidney disease, dehydration, high protein diet, heart failure, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
fieldData.faq-3-answer: This ratio helps distinguish kidney disease from other causes of elevated BUN. A high ratio may indicate dehydration or GI bleeding.
fieldData.faq-4-question: Is BUN the same as creatinine?
fieldData.faq-4-answer: No, but both assess kidney function. BUN is affected by diet and hydration. Creatinine is more specific to kidney function.
fieldData.featured-testimonial-quote: "High BUN turned out to be dehydration, not kidney disease. Good to know the difference."
fieldData.meta-title: BUN Test at Home | Blood Urea Nitrogen | Superpower
fieldData.meta-description: Check BUN (blood urea nitrogen) at home. Assess kidney function and hydration. Results in 5 days. Only $17/month.
fieldData.condition-overview: BUN measures how well kidneys remove urea waste. Combined with creatinine, it provides a complete picture of kidney function.
fieldData.why-test: BUN is part of comprehensive kidney assessment. It can also indicate hydration status and protein metabolism.
fieldData.what-is-included: Your panel includes BUN, creatinine, BUN/creatinine ratio, and eGFR for complete kidney evaluation.
fieldData.next-steps: If BUN is abnormal, our care team explains likely causes—kidney function, hydration, or diet—and recommends appropriate follow-up.
